column3: Description
Context or conditions within which processing takes place
The source or origin of data
column7: Source' is the direct point of data collection; 'origin' would indicate the original/others points of where the data originates from.
column12: Georg P Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Beatriz Esteves

column3: A source of data that is publicly accessible or available
column7: The term 'Public' is used here in a broad sense. Actual consideration of what is 'Public Data' can vary based on several contextual or jurisdictional factors such as  definition of open, methods of access, permissions and licenses.
column12: Georg P Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Beatriz Esteves, Paul Ryan, Julian Flake

column3: A source of data that is not publicly accessible or available
column12: Georg P Krog, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Beatriz Esteves, Paul Ryan, Julian Flake

column3: Processing that involves systematic monitoring of individuals
Processing that involves evaluation and scoring of individuals
Processing that involves matching and combining of personal data
Processing that takes place at large scales
Processing that involves use of innovative and new technologies
Deletion or Erasure of data including any deletion guarantees
column12: Axel Polleres, Rob Brennan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Mark Lizar

column3: Duration or temporal limitation on storage of personal data
column12: Axel Polleres, Rob Brennan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Mark Lizar

column3: Location or geospatial scope where the data is stored
column12: Axel Polleres, Rob Brennan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Mark Lizar

column3: Regularity and temporal span of data restoration/backup mechanisms that guarantee that data is preserved
column12: Axel Polleres, Rob Brennan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Mark Lizar

column3: Conditions required or followed regarding storage of data
column12: Axel Polleres, Rob Brennan, Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Mark Lizar

column3: Contextual information about the degree of automation and human involvement associated with Processing
column7: It is difficult to provide a formal definition of automation since any and all processing may be considered automation. This concept instead is intended to explicitly signal the utilisation of automation and its extent towards some context - such as decision making, and to indicate the involvement of humans.

column3: Processing that is automated and involves verification of outputs by Humans
column7: For example, a human verifying outputs of an algorithm for correctness or impact to individuals

column3: Processing that is automated and involves oversight by Humans
column7: For example, a human watching metrics to ensure correctness of procedural values and outputs as processing takes place

column3: Processing that is automated and involves inputs by Humans
column7: For example, an algorithm that takes inputs from humans and performs operations based on them

column3: Processing that is fully automated
Processing that is partially automated or semi-automated
column7: For example, a series of distinct processing operations that are automated individually or have some human involvement

column3: Processing that is completely un-automated or fully manual
column7: For example, a human performing some processing operation

column3: Processing that involves automated decision making
column7: Automated decision making can be defined as “the ability to make decisions by technological means without human involvement.” (“Guidelines on Automated individual decision-making and Profiling for the purposes of Regulation 2016/679 (wp251rev.01)”, 2018, p. 8)

column3: The involvement of humans in specified context
column7: Human Involvement here broadly refers to any involvement by a human in the context of carrying out processing. This may include verification of outcomes, providing input data for making decisions, or overseeing activities.

column3: The algorithmic logic applied or used
column7: Algorithmic Logic is intended as a broad concept for explaining the use of algorithms and automated decisions making within Processing. To describe the actual algorithm, see the Algorithm concept.

column3: A measurement along some dimension
column7: Scales are subjective concepts that need to be defined and interpreted within the context of their application. For example, what would be small within one context could be large within another.
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Rana Saniei

column3: Volume or Scale of Data
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Rana Saniei

column3: Data volume that is considered huge or more than large within the context
Data volume that is considered large within the context
Data volume that is considered medium i.e. neither large nor small within the context
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Paul Ryan

column3: Data volume that is considered small or limited within the context
Data volume that is considered sporadic or sparse within the context
Data volume that is considered singular i.e. a specific instance or single item
Scale of Data Subject(s)
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Rana Saniei

column3: Scale of data subjects considered huge or more than large within the context
Scale of data subjects considered large within the context
Scale of data subjects considered medium i.e. neither large nor small within the context
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Paul Ryan

column3: Scale of data subjects considered small or limited within the context
Scale of data subjects considered sporadic or sparse within the context
Scale of data subjects considered singular i.e. a specific data subject
Indicate of scale in terms of geographic coverage
column12: Harshvardhan J. Pandit, Georg P Krog, Paul Ryan

column3: Geographic coverage spanning the entire globe
Geographic coverage nearly spanning the entire globe
Geographic coverage spanning multiple nations
Geographic coverage spanning a nation
Geographic coverage spanning a specific region or regions
Geographic coverage spanning a specific locality
column7: For example, geographic scale of a city or an area within a city

column3: Geographic coverage spanning a specific environment within the locality
column7: For example, geographic scale of an event take place in a specific building or room
